results.title: [This week in Britain. No. 152: penicillin]
results.brief_description: Newsreel report on developments in penicillin research. Gives a brief history of the discovery of penicillin in 1929 by Alexander Fleming, and the subsequent work 10 years later in Oxford to isolate the germ killer within penicillin and producing it in stabilised form. Film is shown of work progressing in the laboratory of the research teams and in the new production plant. An interview with Frank Doyle, head of the chemical department, discusses a new oral form of penicillin being developed, and new compound [Selbenin?] which combats resistant staphylococcal bacteria in hospitals.

results.title: [This week in Britain. No. 15. Nursery schools]
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine item: East End of London - one of the most densely populated areas in the world - Rachel McMillan Nursery School. Activities at the world’s first nursery school established by the McMillan sisters over fifty years before this film was made. Presented by Noelene Pritchard.

results.title: [This week in Britain. Don't shoot the pianist]
results.brief_description: A segment from ‘This Week in Britain’ discussing the work of the National Film Archive, a division of the British Film Institute, in collecting and preserving film for posterity. Explains the problems associated with storing nitrate film, the procedures used for copying old film, and video taping.

results.title: [The Working women's centre]
results.creator_credit: Laura Butterworth, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As the Working Women’s Centre in South Australia faces budget cuts, Laura Butterworth reflects on the history of the centre, the stories of the women workers and the battles fought and won.

results.title: [The White continent]
results.brief_description: In late 1949, a joint expedition planned by the Governments of Britain, Norway and Sweden left for Queen Maude Land on the Antarctic continent - this was to be the first truly international expedition to the Antarctic. The film covers the first stage of the journey, from departure point in Europe to the establishment of the base camps and later withdrawal of the ship’s party, leaving the groups of scientists to their study of the unknown world of ice and snow. Photography by Tom Stobart.

results.title: [The Story of the Kelly gang] (AFC)
results.brief_description: Fragments of Australia’s first feature film which ran for over an hour. It was possibly the world’s first feature. Includes two sequences which might have been outtakes. One is a confrontation between Ned Kelly and a police constable, and the other a shootout between the gang and the police.

results.title: [The Stars who made the cinema]
results.brief_description: A series of vignettes from silent films with musical background made for the opening of the National Film Theatre, London, featuring the stars of many silent films in famous excerpts. Includes Rudolph Valentino with Vilma Banky in “The Black Eagle”, Conrad Veidt, Buster Keaton in “The General”, Charlie Chaplin in the “Pawnshop”, Lilian Gish in “Hearts of the World”, Mary Pickford, Harry Langdon and many others.
